newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission to adopt two papers on Internet.
newsitem.headline: Commission to adopt two papers on Internet.

text.p: The European Commission on Wednesday will take a first stab at one of the hottest potatoes on its political agenda -- how to prevent paedophiles and other criminals from misusing the Internet.

But the Commission, reacting to a Belgian child-sex and murder scandal which threw the spotlight onto the worldwide phenomenon of paedophilia, will fall short of proposing concrete, legally-binding measures, EU officials say.

Industry Commissioner Martin Bangemann will instead outline in a communication a series of policy options that in the short term could help keep child pornography and other illegal material off the Internet, EU officials said.

They include strengthened cooperation between member states to apply existing rules, self-regulation by associations of Internet service providers, and extended use of filtering software and rating systems allowing users to block access to listed messages.
But encouragement, recommendation and examination will be the keywords rather than regulation, the officials said.

Keyword searches of the World Wide Web, after the bodies of four girls - alleged victims of convicted child rapist Marc Dutroux were found in Belgium -- showed thousands of messages about paedophiles and paedophilia. The Internet, where anonymity can be ensured, is almost impossible to police.
The Commission will argue on Wednesday that while misuse of the Internet is limited compared with its social, educational and cultural benefits, it is too wide to be ignored.
However, it believes the Internet's technical features, worldwide nature and unlimited accessibility mean that new legislation might not be the best way to fight crime.
The Commission will endorse a plan agreed by the Industry Council last week to have Germany host a global conference on ways to prevent misuse of the Internet and other information networks.
It will also set up a site on the World Wide Web including information about technical, legal and other solutions to the problem, officials said.

Culture Commissioner Marcelino Oreja will present a complementary green paper aimed at examining medium and long-term ideas for protecting minors and human dignity on a whole range of new audiovisual services, which he says include online services.
Oreja has opted for a softly-softly approach, saying he fears too-impulsive action could hinder the public benefits of the Internet and hinder freedom of expression.
His consultations with industry, government and family groups will focus on regulation versus self-regulation, parental control systems and improving international cooperation, officials said.
Interested parties will have until next February to answer a list of nine questions.
